clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Binaural Beats on Pain Perception and Analgesic Medication Use in Patients Suffering From Chronic Pain
clinical_study.official_title: Placebo-Controlled, Randomized, Double-Blind Trial on the Effect of Binaural Beats on Pain Perception and Analgesic Medication Use in Patients Suffering From Chronic Pain

brief_summary.textblock: This study evaluates the effect of binaural beats on pain perception and subsequent need for analgesic medication use in patients suffering from diseases causing chronic pain. All patients will receive two consecutive interventions: binaural beat signals embedded in relaxing music and placebo (relaxing music without the binaural beat component), in random order.

detailed_description.textblock:
Binaural beats consist of two artificially produced sound waves, differing in wave frequency, presented simultaneously and separately to each ear. The brain, following binaural beat processing, synchronizes to the frequency difference between the two waves. Therefore, using a 5 Hz frequency difference (theta rhythm), which promotes relaxation, we could alleviate pain perception and subsequent analgesic medication use.
Patients suffering from chronic pain will receive two consecutive interventions: binaural beat signals embedded in relaxing music and placebo (relaxing music without the binaural beat component), in random order.
Electroencephalogram (EEG) recordings will be used to confirm brain frequency synchronization, whereas pain severity scales and a diary recording analgesic medication use will be used to identify differences between intervention and placebo arms.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.time_frame: After 30 minutes of listening to binaural beat signals or sham intervention
primary_outcome.description: Comparing pre- and post-intervention perceived pain levels, using a Numeric Rating Scale (NRS) 0-10

primary_outcome.time_frame: One week on an "as needed" basis intervention use to alleviate pain, keeping a diary
primary_outcome.description: Comparing analgesic medication active substance quantity used, documented on patient diary recordings

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 30 minutes of listening to binaural beat signals or sham intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Evaluating differences in post-intervention EEG rhythm, using advanced biomedical signal processing, compared to baseline EEG rhythm

arm_group.description: Music with Binaural Beats: Binaural beat signals embedded in relaxing music, in a crossover design
Music: Relaxing music without the binaural beat component, in a crossover design

intervention.description: Relaxing music with embedded binaural beats at a frequency of 5 Hz
Relaxing music without a binaural beat component

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Chronic pain
- Regular analgesic medication use
Exclusion Criteria:
- Malignant pain
- Headache as the cause of chronic pain
- Hearing disability
- Neuropsychiatric disease
- Previous experience with binaural beats
